title: Ticket #5152: Perform spool removal out-of-process
description:

Can we move the recursive chown and/or removal out-of-process?

remarks:
2015-Jul-16 20:44:25 by bbockelm:
Just poked through the spool cleanup code a bit more.
  • We recursively chown the spool directory to user condor, then spawn /bin/rm to do the dirty work. CMS spool directories can have tens-of-thousands of files, making the unnecessary clonej() a very expensive operation.
  • Spawning a separate process costs about 250ms (which honestly we don't have...)

If we have to leave this work in-process, doing it more efficiently would really help.

2015-Jul-27 14:01:19 by jfrey:
One option is to remove the chown entirely. That is, the job's spool directory would be owned by the user for its entire lifetime.

2015-Jul-28 14:09:40 by bbockelm:
Hi Jaime,

I'm not sure of the impact of removing the chown in all cases - I think there's some good reasons why it's chown'd during hold, for example (I don't know what these are).

But certainly, in this particular case (chown is followed up by rm immediately) it seems we can remove the chown.

Brian
